LeadText.textfield: Language is not just what we say, but how we say it. Scania’s tone of voice is honest, sincere, respectful and confident. Typography is the visualisation of our voice.

section.Title: Introduction
section.Text:
For a strong and unified brand expression, Scania has developed a custom-made and unique font family — Scania Sans. Our typeface has a strong Scania DNA since it derives from our wordmark.

We use typography to present information and structure the entire user interface with clear hierarchy.

section.Title: Functional & Expressive
section.Text:
At Scania, we have divided our typography into two type sets, Functional and Expressive. These two types have different purposes, but there might be applications where a combination of them could be used. **Functional**
Should be used in non-branded communication, information and documentation. The main usage is for Scania applications (except apps used in-vehicle), where the typography’s focus is to help the user understand and perform tasks. **Expressive**
Should be used for more branded external communication and public websites, for instance Scania.com. These types of applications need a much stronger expression for the typography, especially when it comes to headlines. Learn more about each specific type set: [Functional type](link) [Expressive type](link)

section.Title: Typeface
section.Text:
The Scania Sans typeface family has several fonts and weights, making it ideal for every context and every occasion, from bold and inspiring headlines to informative footnotes..

The typeface family has four fonts:
— Scania Sans Headline
— Scania Sans
— Scania Sans Semi Condensed
— Scania Sans Condensed

section.Title: Type settings
section.Text:
We use four type settings when applying typography within our user interfaces. These type settings have several text styles that could be found at [Functional type](link) and [Expressive type](link). **Headline**
Used to create clear typographic hierarchies. **Paragraph**
Use for introduction texts. **Body**
Used primarily for longer body texts, intro texts and specific components. **Detail**
Used for captions, detailed text, table, component and code related typography.

section.Title: Type scale
section.Text:
When designing and creating new layouts and applications, you should use any of our defined type sets Functional or Expressive, depending on what you’re designing for. This scale will help you create consistent layouts with a balanced rhythm. In some specific scenarios, you might end up needing a size that is not specified within those type sets. When adding a new text style, you should select a size from our type scale below to get a cohesive typographic experience.
Rem Pixel Example

section.Title: Tokens
section.Text:
For managing our typography, we use tokens that have defined all our typographic settings such as font size, font weight, letter height and letter spacing. These tokens should be used when designing a new page layout or application.

Visit [Functional type](link) and [Expressive type](link) to get a full overview of which tokens that are available within each type set.

section.Title: Fallback
section.Text:
When Scania Sans fail to load due to technical issues or when technical restrictions or special glyphs for languages limits the use of Scania Sans typeface, the following replacement fonts – or similar - are recommended: **Mac computers**
Helvetica Neue **PC computers**
Arial

LeadText.textfield: Spacing is just as important as the Unit and Grid System. It helps us to create a harmonious layout, with both vertical and horizontal rhythm.

section.Title: Introduction
section.Text:
By having clear spacing scales, we limit the layout to make use of only a specific number of units instead of using a wide span of various spacing options which quickly escalates and creates an inconsistent experience. We also make sure that we are consistent across our entire components library.

At Scania, we use two spacing scales which both are based on our Unit System; layout scale and element scale. Both the scales are applicable on vertical and horizontal edges.

section.Title: Layout scale
section.Text:
The layout scale is used when we position content, components and patterns on a page layout. This scale should always be used when creating new layouts. 

Should an application need an additional spacing size, make sure to use our Unit System as base to create a consistent spacing scale when creating a new token.

Rem Pixel Token Scale
2 8 $spacing-layout-8
4 16 $spacing-layout-16
6 24 $spacing-layout-24
8 32 $spacing-layout-32
12 48 $spacing-layout-48
16 64 $spacing-layout-64
24 96 $spacing-layout-96
32 128 $spacing-layout-128
40 160 $spacing-layout-160
![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/40fe6a47ccd145eeabd06df1272108b0.png)

section.Title: Element scale
section.Text:
The element scale is used when building components where we need smaller units to work with, when defining all detailed work within a component. Should a component need an additional spacing size, make sure to use our Unit System as base to create a consistent spacing scale, when creating a new token.

section.Title: Exceptions
section.Text:
There are exceptions within Scania user interfaces where we don’t use our spacing element token for spacing elements.

**Centre**
This is used when we contextually need to centre an element between two edges, for instance a text within a specific button component.

Currently, the UI Kit is work in progress. It will be available to download here in Q1.
At Scania, we use two systems to manage our layout and grid — the Unit and the Grid System. These two systems are the fundament to everything that we design and develop.

LeadText.textfield: At Scania, we have two levels of working in design.

section.Text:
##### 1. Way of working between the UX design team and the Agile development team

It is recommended that UX design stage precedes Agile development stage. In practice, the UX design stage is recommended to be carried out at two levels. One, at meta level where the information architecture (IA) of the solution is carried out and finalized in collaboration with the development team. At the same time, this stage of UX design also delivers detailed wireframes, including the behaviour of the interactive elements, that are evaluated with the intended users. Once this is finalised, it provides the vision for the development team. 

The development team then breaks down the vision in terms of epics, stories and sub tasks and prioritize them for development. Two, at micro level, where UX design team details out the wireframes – for the epic/story prioritised for development - and provides UI specifications for development. This stage of UX design works in parallel with development and provides continuous contribution as required by the epic/story. Once an epic/story is implemented and tested, the UX design team, moves on to the next sprint/development stage and repeats above mentioned tasks based on the epic/story. This continues until the end of the project.

##### 2. The way of working within the UX team

UX team is, ideally, a multidisciplinary team with its members coming from a variety of disciplines, such as, design, computer science, graphic design, psychology, anthropology, sociology etc. It is not always the case that the UX design team will have this kind of diversity. At the same time, it is common for UX designers (through their education and experience) to have a good level of competence (originating from a variety of fields, such as sociology, design etc.) to run all aspects of the UX design process.

Given this, the UX design team should assess their competencies via a vis UX various stages of UX design process (such as, research, design, prototyping and evaluation) and assign responsibilities of conducting each such stages amongst themselves.

The UX design process, then, is carried out iteratively, in a sprint like fashion. That is, when the first cycle of UX design process constituting of research, design, prototyping and evaluation is complete and reflected upon (to access if the solution arrived at meets the needs of the intended users), another cycle of UX design process is carried out and the same is repeated until the solution arrived at addresses the needs of the intended users in the best possible manner and at an optimum cost.

LeadText.textfield: A divider is a 1px line that help us group and separate content within our layouts, components and patterns.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text:
Dividers help us both to group and to separate content. We use dividers within our page layouts and also within our components and patterns.

They should be used sparingly and only if we can’t separate content using white space. Too many dividers present on a small surface will be perceived as a cluttered and busy experience.

section.Title: Types
section.Text:
We have two different types of dividers, full-bleed dividers and indent dividers. Each type has a horizontal and vertical version.

##### Full-bleed dividers
Full-bleed dividers are as the name describes, full-bleed components. This means that a full-bleed divider is aligned with the margins of the component or the page.

This type of dividers is used to separate different sections within a layout, to separate unrelated texts inside lists (for instance a data table) and to separate content inside a header for instance.

##### Indent dividers

The opposite to full-bleed dividers is our indent dividers. They have the same visual appearance and what separates them is that these do not behave as a full-bleed component. Indent dividers are used to separate related content, inside lists or data tables for instance.

section.Title: Colour
section.Text:
Dividers come in different colours. Depending on what theme or background colour the divider exists on, the colour of the divider varies.

On our lightest backgrounds, the colour of the divider will be the next step above the background colour. For instance, $white background equals $grey-100 divider and $grey-100 background equals $grey-200 divider. 

On background colours with 300 or higher, colour of the divider will be the next step below the background colour. For instance, $grey-300 background equals $grey-200 divider.

The exception is when we reach the highest step within a colour, 900. Then we will use 700 as divider colour to make sure that we have a good contrast between the divider and the background.

Examples
Background Divider colour
$white $grey-100
$grey-100 $grey-200
$grey-200 $grey-300
$grey-300 $grey-200
$grey-400 $grey-300
$grey-500 $grey-400
$grey-600 $grey-500
$grey-700 $grey-600
$grey-800 $grey-700
$grey-900 $grey-700

section.Title: Specs
section.Text: Our dividers, both full-bleed and indents, have a width of 1 px / 0.25 rem.
